Cecil Gaines.Action: Responds politely and positively about all presidents, avoiding favoritism.
Expresses dislike for Annabeth Lewis using a sharp metaphor.
Remembers childhood fearfully but does not express bitterness openly here.
Smiles politely and diplomatically when asked about his favorite president, despite personal feelings.
Uses humor and wit to deflect a difficult question about people he disliked.
Remains silent and submissive in the face of harsh verbal abuse as a child, showing fear but no overt resistance.
Pays close attention to Annabeth’s serving, tries to hold his breath to avoid making noise, mimics pouring water lying awake at night.
Pours iced tea for Annabeth and tries to accommodate her changing preferences despite his visible disappointment.
Places iced tea and various condiments thoughtfully for Annabeth Lewis, and respectfully bows after stirring her drink despite her brusque dismissal.
Attempts to engage with Annabeth by answering her question honestly but accepts her curt gesture without complaint.
Reads quietly by himself at night, persevering despite confusion, showing sincerity and humility.

Presents a self-critical internal view suggesting bitterness about reading (thinking books were worst thing that happened to him), indicating internal struggle but no direct warmth or coldness to others.
Works cooperatively and efficiently alongside Annabeth in serving the family, showing teamwork and dedication.
Smiles at the white hoboes in the freight train car, showing friendliness despite their grimy appearance and lack of reciprocation.
Feels surprised and hurt when Annabeth dismisses his decision to leave after years together, indicating emotional sensitivity and sincerity.
Decides to leave to see the world after saving money for almost three years.
Reacts to hostility and violence from white crowd on the bread line by running away.
Turns away from throwing a rock through a window and instead walks toward a glowing light, showing fascination rather than anger or destruction.
Faces a hostile Head Butler with a warm smile and calm demeanor, responding sincerely and peacefully.
Approaches the glowing light of the hotel with fascination instead of destructive intent.
Faces the Head Butler’s harsh interrogation with a warm smile and composed confidence.
Initially picks up a rock to throw through the store window in frustration.
Comforts Gloria, a crying maid, and helps remove a wine stain from her shirt to save her job.
Responds modestly when Gloria praises him as kind.
Serves cocktails at wedding reception, shows embarrassment, but accepts Gloria taking over with no complaint.
Slow dances tenderly with Gloria, foreheads touching, madly in love.
Expresses sincere love and commitment to Gloria, promising to care for her and build a family.
Pensive about Annabeth Lewis, expresses sadness for her despite referring to her as 'mean ole cracker woman.'
Serves cocktails at the wedding reception while feeling embarrassed and unsure.
Expresses deep commitment to his wife, promising to take care of his family and provide stability.
Looks slightly terrified at his own wedding, indicating some insecurity in personal situations.
Gives Louis an understanding wink when he declines to join the group, showing emotional intelligence and supportive parenting.
Smiles warmly but shows slight concern for Louis’s uncertainty, indicating awareness of his son's needs and thoughtful reflection.
Responds calmly and diplomatically to a provocative and racist question in front of wealthy men, maintaining composure and using refined language.
Catches the scotch knocked off the table by the Loud Patron and calmly lights the Crew Cut Man’s cigar with his other hand.
Responds thoughtfully to the Loud Patron’s aggressive political statement without escalating the tension.
Refrains from immediately answering his son Louis’s painful question about Emmett Till’s murder; hesitates to explain harsh realities.
Catches the scotch knocked off the table in one motion and lights the Crew Cut Man's cigar with the other hand.
Responds to a provocative comment about Judge Earl Warren with composed and measured words, 'I think Judge Warren is going to find that quite a challenge.'
Avoids answering his son Louis's difficult question directly about racial violence and injustice, instead giving a vague explanation about the law being different for colored people.
Advises his son Louis to stay out of trouble with the law to be safe, showing protective concern.
Responds politely and with calm respect to the Hotel Manager despite confusion and concern.
Shows humility and curiosity when speaking with Freddie Fallows, refraining from boasting despite the surprise call.
Recognizes subtle rejection from Freddie Fallows, demonstrating social awareness but no hostility or defensiveness.
Explains to his son Louis about the racial realities with calmness and pragmatism.
Responds calmly and clearly to the Hotel Manager's questioning about law trouble, showing composure.
Approaches the Blair House with confidence, taking a breath before entering, indicating self-preparedness.
Engages with Freddie Fallows politely and professionally, maintaining composure despite being initially unwelcome.
Does not react negatively or defensively to Freddie's icy demeanor, instead continuing the conversation with measured respect.
Politely refuses a job offer that would make others uncomfortable, showing awareness of work dynamics and confidence in his own standards.
Engages Freddie in knowledgeable conversation about crystal quality, demonstrating attentive observation and confidence in his expertise.
Presents himself in a perfectly tailored tuxedo, eliciting pride and admiration from family, reflecting his pride and professional presentation skills.
Surveys the White House employees parking lot and surroundings with wide-eyed awe.
Steps forward to thank RD Warner politely for the opportunity, showing gratitude and respect.
Acknowledges the snub from RD Warner without complaint or visible anger, showing tolerance.
Questions the large staff allocation, showing attention to detail and curiosity about workflow efficiency.

Avoids political discussion initially, indicating caution rather than openness.

Shows warmth and friendliness to Carter, quickly establishing camaraderie.
Does not engage in the provocative or potentially divisive language Booker uses.
Gives a slight head bow and respectfully greets Mrs. Eisenhower, calling it a true honor.
Nods attentively while Freddie explains the strict rules of service, showing respect and earnestness.
Says ‘--emptier when I’m in it’ referring to not reacting to conversations during service, indicating a reserved and self-effacing demeanor.
Shows respect and carefulness while serving tea to the president despite nervousness.
Avoids staring but openly acknowledges Eisenhower's grandfatherly warmth.
Successfully carries a teapot on a silver tray in a formal setting for his first serving in the White House.
Despite nervousness and shaking hands, he steadies the teacup and carefully sets it down on the President's desk, managing the situation without obvious mistake.
Shows visible nervousness (sweat, rattling hands) during an important moment serving the President, suggesting some initial lack of confidence.
Pours tea carefully despite shaking hands, cleans spill discreetly to avoid notice.
Tries to be as obsequious as possible when serving tea.
Hurries out of the Oval Office sweating and fearful, showing vulnerability but no direct engagement.
Pouring tea carefully while visibly shaking, managing to clean spilled tea before anyone notices.
Sweating, shaking, and internally admitting fear and inattentiveness during a critical meeting in the Oval Office.
Explains the butler's code that they know everything but tell nothing, maintaining confidentiality.
Denies Louis permission to attend Mamie Till's speech, despite Louis’ clear enthusiasm and disappointment.
Maintains confidentiality about what the President talked about, standing firm on the butler's code of silence.
Refuses to allow his son Louis to attend a civil rights event, reasoning that nothing good can come of it.

Watches the President's announcement about integration along with other kitchen staff, sharing a moment of pride.
Does not engage in direct confrontation or express frustration about the racial injustice described, remains composed and reserved.
Serves the President attentively by bringing coffee and engaging respectfully in conversation.
Answers honestly about his background, showing straightforwardness rather than evasion.
Observes and reacts calmly to tense situations around him without showing panic or confusion.
Encourages and supports his son Louis going off to college despite his own pain and fear of distance.
Hugs Louis tightly and expresses pride and love before his departure.
Attempts to smile through pain, showing emotional restraint but underlying care.
Encourages and supports his son Louis's decision to attend a distant college despite his own pain and fear of losing him.
Struggles emotionally with letting his son go but ultimately manages to say supportive words and release him.
Shows understanding of the social realities (segregation at graduation) but does not vocalize or act on addressing it in this scene.
Smiles with pride when recalling his service to presidents and sharing stories warmly with the camera man.
Helps the pastry chef with making an elaborate dessert enthusiastically alongside his coworkers.
Supports Vice-President Nixon by putting on campaign buttons and cheering him on.
When asked about concerns with civil rights, deflects and says he just wants his son to have a good education.
Responds to Nixon's question by deflecting from civil rights to focus on his son's education, avoiding confrontation or political discussion.
Shrugs and admits he doesn't really know why his son is going to Fisk University in the deep South.
Responds confidently to Nixon's skeptical questioning about his son's education plans by calmly shrugging, showing composure despite uncertainty.
Elegantly serves filet of sole to guests at the White House dinner.

Stands at attention with butlers during a formal event, demonstrating discipline and readiness.

Scolds Louis harshly for participating in civil rights protests, expressing fear and anger about potential harm.
Expresses deep concern for his son's safety and future, revealing protective care and strong paternal love.
Scolds his son Louis firmly and expresses concern about Louis' involvement in civil rights protests, emphasizing a pragmatic view of danger and consequences.

Shines shoes carefully and speaks directly to the camera about the difficulty of transition, displaying self-awareness and responsibility.

Sets tea in front of Bobby without acknowledgement, Bobby doesn’t look up.
